question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the generated code is executable for demonstration. Please use HBuilder to develop a uniapp that calls the Android device camera to measure tree diameter at breast height (DBH), with the following requirements: 1. The interface should be visually appealing and appropriate for the forestry industry; 2. After opening the interface, the device camera should automatically start, displaying the image in the photo area; 3. Add two vertical thin red lines in the photo area as reference lines for tree boundaries, which can be moved manually; 4. When clicking the measurement button, take a photo of the tree while calculating and displaying the DBH measurement result.

checklist.title: Is the camera functionality fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements camera integration through uniapp APIs, including automatic camera startup, real-time preview display, and photo capture functionality. Check if camera permissions are properly requested and handled. Score 0 if camera doesn't work, 5 if only basic capture is implemented, and 10 if all camera features including preview, capture, and permission handling are fully functional.

checklist.title: Are the movable reference lines properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the two vertical red reference lines are correctly overlaid on the camera preview, can be moved manually through touch gestures, and maintain proper positioning during camera operations. Check if the lines have appropriate visual styling (thin, red, clearly visible). Deduct 5 points if lines are not movable, 3 points if touch interaction is unresponsive, and 5 points if lines disappear during camera operations. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the DBH measurement algorithm accurate and reliable?
checklist.description: Check whether the measurement calculation uses proper scaling algorithms based on reference objects or camera parameters to convert pixel distance to real-world measurements. Evaluate if the algorithm accounts for distance, camera angle, and provides reasonable DBH values. Deduct 5 points if no scaling mechanism exists, 3 points if measurements are consistently inaccurate, and 5 points if the algorithm doesn't handle edge cases. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the forestry-themed interface design professionally implemented?
checklist.description: Assess whether the interface design appropriately reflects forestry industry aesthetics with nature-inspired color schemes, professional measurement tool styling, and industry-appropriate iconography. Check if the interface includes proper measurement units display, clear result presentation, and forestry-specific visual elements. Deduct 5 points if the design looks generic, 3 points if forestry context is missing, and 5 points if the interface appears unprofessional. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as camera access denial, device orientation changes, measurement calculation errors, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should effectively handle camera failures, permission issues, and measurement edge cases, giving 10 points. If robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that enhance measurement accuracy?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes advanced features that improve measurement precision (e.g., 1. Auto-detection of tree edges 2. Multiple measurement averaging 3. Calibration using known reference objects 4. Measurement history with GPS location). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature that enhances measurement functionality (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple photo capture methods) 2. Function modules unrelated to tree measurement (e.g., built-in photo filters) 3. Excessive visual effects that impact performance (e.g., complex animations during measurement). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if core measurement functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating camera logic/measurement algorithms/UI components), proper uniapp project structure, and code organization. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or component architecture is poor; deduct 5 points if code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if uniapp best practices are not followed. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional forestry application standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the design follows forestry application principles: 1) Nature-appropriate color palette (greens, browns, earth tones) 2) Clear measurement display with proper units and precision 3) Professional tool-like interface with good contrast for outdoor use. Deduct 3 points for each unclear measurement display, 5 points for inappropriate color choices that don't suit forestry context, and 5 points for poor readability in bright outdoor conditions. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the touch interaction smooth and measurement-focused?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interactions are optimized for field measurement use: 1) Reference line dragging responds within 100ms 2) Measurement button provides immediate visual feedback 3) Results display clearly with appropriate precision 4) Interface remains stable during device movement. Deduct 5 points for each unresponsive interaction, 3 points for laggy reference line movement, and 5 points for unclear measurement result presentation. Full score is 10 points.
